Triumphant Time!  thy wayward course began</br>Ere young creation's bloom was fresh and new;</br>When to illume the heritage of Man</br>The light of Eden sparkled on the view;</br>When earth was fair, and every breeze that blew</br>Across her bosom murmured gently by,</br>Full-fraught with fragrance; ere the tempest flew</br>In fearful gloominess to veil the sky,</br>To shroud its beams and hide its golden dye.

Then Man was happy, innocent and young,</br>His hope unclouded as the heaven above;</br>Then angel woman to his bosom clung,</br>And wakened all her witchery of love:</br>She came from heaven like the Almighty dove,</br>To win his soul with seraph tenderness,</br>Her flowery bonds of bliss she interwove,</br>To bind his spirit in her fond caress,</br>And life was blessed, bright, and sorrowless.

Then, then, oh Time!  thy wing was waving light,</br>To fan the flowers that beautified thy way;</br>Then was existence teeming with delight,</br>And sparkling in a gay and glorious day;</br>Then was the spirit, in its mortal clay,</br>Breathing as with a pure celestial glow;</br>But sin and sorrow came in dread array,</br>To blight the buds and lay the blossoms low,</br>And earth became an heritage of woe.

Ah, mournful change!  that paradise, so fair,</br>So beautiful and fragrant in its bloom,</br>And glorious spring, and primal freshness — there</br>Came Melancholy in her shroud of gloom,</br>And Care to waste, to wither, and consume</br>The aching spirit in untimely blight:</br>Then bent the soul of Man beneath its doom,</br>When Innocence and Virtue took their flight</br>And left the world involved in Sorrow's night.

Yet still hath Man a ray of bliss on earth—</br>The garden of his life hath still a hue—</br>While shines his morning in its hour of mirth,</br>Cloudless awhile, and robed as yet in blue:—</br>That germ of paradise, so fair to view,</br>Is fond Affection's first and purest spring,</br>When each emotion of the heart is true,</br>Ere hope hath lost her buoyancy of wing,</br>Or the cold world hath brought its withering.

Oh, ever dear and hallowed be the hour</br>When angel Love descended on rosy wing,</br>To cull the blossoms in life's young May-bower,</br>And lull the anguish of Affliction's sting!</br>Oh, ever blessed be that holy spring</br>Whence flow the streams of love and faithfulness,</br>In purest waves of gentle murmuring,</br>Shedding a balm on every rude distress—</br>Fountains of bliss in the world's wilderness!

Oh, ever clear and hallowed be the hour!</br>Let youth enjoy it ere its sweets are fled;</br>Ere the dark storms of destiny shall lour</br>And break in rude commotion o'er the head;</br>When the fierce shaft of misery hath sped</br>Unto the breast, and griefs are gathering rife,</br>The memory of its blessings shall be shed,</br>A beam of gladness on the world of strife!</br>A rainbow on the shrouded sky of life!

Subduer Time!  Stern conqueror of all!</br>Avenger of the follies of mankind!</br>Pride, honor, power, and grandeur, own thy thrall,</br>And are by the to nothingness consigned!</br>But canst thou master the immortal mind?</br>There, all in vain, dost thou thy fury pour:</br>Its march is onward — free and unconfined—</br>Such as the Roman annals showed of yore,</br>And such as glorified the Grecian shore.

Oh, there was glory's consecrated clime,</br>Where Sappho breath'd, and where Anacreon sung,</br>Where genius nourished in the olden time,</br>And dwelt upon the Athenian's gifted tongue;</br>His, who the thunderbolts at Philip flung,</br>And urged his countrymen the fight to dare.</br>Where heaven itself a Homer's lyre had strung</br>With chord that echoed sweetly on the air,</br>As if the melody of heaven was there!

And there was Valour's spirit, proud and high,</br>Which shone resplendent on the cloud of war;</br>Where Mars himself poured forth his battle-cry</br>And lash'd the coursers to his blood-dyed car,</br>As shone the ray of conquest from afar,</br>The beacon of each hero, on whose eye</br>It beamed a guiding and a natal star,</br>Like Israel's fiery pillar, streaming high,</br>And blazing bright athwart the Egyptian sky!

There fell the Spartan — fearlessly he fell,</br>And smil'd in the red agony of death;</br>Yea, there was triumph in his battle-knell,</br>And victory in every ebb of breath;</br>Undying glory twined the laurel wreath</br>Bound the lone cypress that o'ershades the grave,</br>Memorial of the one who slept beneath,</br>Of him whose life blood pour'd forth like the wave—</br>The young, the proud, the generous, the brave!

Undying glory!  Man may pass away</br>Like the light bubble floating on the stream,</br>Like the expiring blossom of a day,</br>Or the frail dew-drop in the sunny beam:</br>Yes, short and transitory is his dream</br>Of youthful love, joy's evanescent hour,</br>Of hope's beguiling and bewitching theme;</br>But when the storms of fate and ages lower,</br>Glory defies and mocks their baleful power.

For this, all time hath hallowed the high name</br>Of Helle's chieftain, and of those who led</br>The bold ten thousand of immortal fame</br>Through slaughter's fields o'er heaps of Persian dead;</br>And of that brave Militades, who sped</br>Even as a lion from the forest lair,</br>To hasten where war's banner was outspread,</br>And waving like a silver cloud in air,</br>To try the bloody strife, to fight — to triumph there,

For this, the unfading light of glory smiles</br>On the blue Dardanelles, and on the bay</br>Where in their beauty spread Iona's isles,</br>Washed and enwreathed around by ocean's spray—</br>For this, eternal Summer sheds her ray</br>On high Parnassus, and that Helicon,</br>Where the Muse chanted her bewitching lay</br>In days of yore — that melody is gone,</br>And those loved bowers are desolate and lone.

Yes, here — oh, here the scythe of Time hath swept,</br>The torch of Time hath gone abroad to burn;</br>And here, for many an age, hath genius slept,</br>But not unhonoured, in the noiseless urn—</br>Still doth the eye, with kind expression turn</br>To that illustrious and all hallowed clime,</br>The light of former ages to discern,</br>When genius flourished in its lofty prime,</br>And the mind sprung triumphant over Time!

And thus it is:  kingdoms may fall in dust,</br>The coronals of empire may decay,</br>The sceptre perish, and the helmet rust,</br>And power and proud dominion pass away;</br>These are the transient baubles of a day:</br>But the mind glows in its immortal bloom,</br>And genius sheds an unextinguished ray</br>Upon life's scenes of dreariness and gloom,</br>Victorious over Time — victorious o'er the tomb!</br>
